Hey {first_name, "there"},

Here in the UK, we're in the grip of a heatwave. This is the one time of year you don't want to live by the beach, as we've been hiding at home, trying to avoid the hordes flocking to our normally peaceful beach. Perhaps it was predictable that, as foreign holidays look more likely to end up in quarantine, that people would make the most of our own coast. 

Still, that means I've had a little time to catch up on some of the interesting a useful pieces published in the last few days. Here's five more that are worth reading over your morning coffee (or tea, smoothies or other beverage).

sections: Podcasts: the new home of investigative journalism?
In the midst of a fairly predictable opinion piece from a podcast platform staffer, this thought stood out:

In recent years, we‚Äôve witnessed the financial investment in traditional journalism depreciate, and with it, the extent to which journalists are able to devote to in-depth investigations. But this hasn‚Äôt been the case in podcasting, as it‚Äôs quickly emerged as a new home of storytelling, with the high audience engagement in audio providing new editorial options. For example, investigative series The Teacher's Pet and The Lady Vanishes have captivated global audiences, with the episodic format of the podcasts allowing the creators to report in real-time on the podcasts.

interesting point. Some investigative journalism lends itself really well to episodic storytelling, drawing the reader along with the journalist as they dig into a story. Podcasts are perfect for episodic storytelling.
Perfect match of story type to story platform.

Twitter is experimenting with more prominently displaying the number of retweets with comments (quote tweets) that a Tweet has, calling them Quotes. I still think that these simple pieces of numerical social proof tend to incentivize attention-seeking behaviour, but we'll see if this makes a difference.
